items.title: Interstellar comet's sunward jets baffle scientists

featured_image.name: Rare interstellar comet 3i/Atlas set to fly past Earth ...

items.description:
The third known interstellar object to visit our solar system continues to puzzle astronomers as it exits toward Jupiter, displaying sunward jets that defy conventional comet physics while yielding no detectable alien signals to radio telescopes scanning for signs of extraterrestrial technology.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, first spotted on July 1, 2025, by the NASA-funded ATLAS survey in Chile, has been the subject of intense scientific scrutiny since its discovery. With the Breakthrough Listen project confirming no technosignatures were detected during five hours of observation using the Green Bank Telescope on December 18, 2025, researchers have largely settled the question of whether this cosmic wanderer might be artificial.[1][2][3]

"We all would have been thrilled to find technosignatures coming from 3I/ATLAS, but they're just not there," Benjamin Jacobson-Bell from the University of California, Berkeley, told Space.com. "Finding no signals was the result we expected, due to the significant evidence for 3I/ATLAS being a comet with only natural features."[4]

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro ordered transferred to maximum-security prison

featured_image.name: BRAZIL-POLITICS-JUSTICE-TRIAL-COUP

items.description:
Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes ordered the transfer of former President Jair Bolsonaro to the Papuda Penitentiary Complex in Brasilia on Thursday, according to court documents released January 15, 2026. The move represents a stark shift in the conditions under which the 70-year-old far-right politician will serve his 27-year sentence for plotting a coup following his 2022 election defeat.[1][2][3]

Bolsonaro has been detained at the Federal Police Superintendency since his arrest in late November 2025, housed in a 12-square-meter room equipped with a bed, private bathroom, air conditioning, television, and desk. Under the new order, he will be relocated to a building within the Papuda complex, Brazil's largest maximum-security penitentiary facility in the capital.[4][5][6][7]

items.title: Venezuela's acting president proposes oil reforms to lure US investment

featured_image.name: Delcy Rodriguez Addresses The Media Regarding The Release Of Prisoners In Venezuela

items.description:
Acting Venezuelan President Delcy Rodríguez has submitted a proposal to reform her country's hydrocarbon law, seeking to open doors to greater US investment in the oil-rich nation less than two weeks after US special forces captured former President Nicolás Maduro in a surprise military operation.[1][2]

Rodríguez announced on Thursday that she was proposing the reforms to Venezuela's National Assembly, a move that addresses a key demand from major American oil companies who have described the country as "uninvestable" under current regulations. At her first press conference since Maduro's ouster, Rodríguez also declared Venezuela was entering a "new political era" marked by greater tolerance toward political rivals.[3][4][1]

items.title: Global AI spending to surge 44% in 2026, Gartner forecasts

featured_image.name: CEO Jensen Huang Just Delivered Fantastic News for Nvidia Investors | The Motley Fool

items.description: The artificial intelligence industry is on track for a historic year, with global spending projected to surge 44% to $2.53 trillion in 2026 before climbing to $3.33 trillion by 2027, according to new forecasts from Gartner released this week. The boom is simultaneously propelling semiconductor revenues past $1 trillion for the first time in the industry's history.

items.title: US and Taiwan reach trade deal cutting tariffs, securing chip investment

featured_image.name: TSMC, the Chip Giant, Is to Spend $100 Billion in U.S. Over the Next ...

items.description:
The United States and Taiwan have reached a trade agreement that will reduce tariffs on Taiwanese goods from 20 percent to 15 percent and secure hundreds of billions of dollars in semiconductor investment commitments, according to officials familiar with the matter. The deal, which the White House was set to announce Thursday, places Taiwan on equal footing with Japan and South Korea, which secured similar arrangements last year.[1][2]

Under the agreement, Taiwanese semiconductor companies will commit to a $500 billion increase in financing for American operations, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. pledging to build at least five additional fabrication plants in Arizona, effectively doubling its manufacturing presence in the state.[2][3][1]

items.title: Trump advisers warned Iran strike unlikely to topple regime

featured_image.name: Trump would want military action in Iran to be swift and decisive ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump's national security advisers have cautioned him that a substantial military strike against Iran would probably not lead to the collapse of the Islamic Republic's government and could instead trigger a wider regional conflict, according to U.S. officials familiar with the discussions. The assessment came as Trump signaled a potential pause in his escalating threats against Tehran, saying Wednesday he had been informed that killings of protesters had stopped.

The president has communicated to his advisers that he wants any military action to be "swift and decisive" and deliver a "definitive" blow to the regime, according to NBC News. However, officials said his team has been unable to guarantee that outcome, with concerns mounting that the United States may lack sufficient military assets in the region to defend against what is expected to be an aggressive Iranian response.[1][2]

items.title: Deforestation pushing mosquitoes to bite humans more, study finds

featured_image.name: Mosquitoes' thirst for human blood has increased as ...

items.description:
As Brazil's Atlantic Forest shrinks and wildlife vanishes, mosquitoes are increasingly targeting humans for their blood meals, raising fresh concerns about the spread of diseases such as dengue, Zika, and yellow fever, according to a study published this week in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution.

The research, conducted by scientists at the Oswaldo Cruz Institute and the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, analyzed blood samples from mosquitoes captured in nature reserves within the Atlantic Forest. The results showed a pronounced shift: of the identifiable blood meals, 18 came from humans—far outpacing other sources, which included only six birds, one amphibian, one rodent, and one canid.[1][2][3]

items.title: Netanyahu asked Trump to delay Iran strike, officials say

featured_image.name: Netanyahu plans to brief Trump on possible new Iran strikes

items.description:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asked President Donald Trump on Wednesday to hold off on a military strike against Iran, according to senior U.S. officials, as four Arab nations conducted urgent diplomacy to avert an American attack that they feared could destabilize the region.

The request from Netanyahu came as Trump appeared to pull back from the brink of military action, telling reporters Wednesday that he had been informed by "very, very important sources on the other side" that the killing of protesters in Iran had stopped and planned executions would not take place.[1][2][3]

items.title: Canada and China sign trade roadmap as Carney makes first Beijing visit in 8 years

featured_image.name: Canadian prime minister visits China after nearly a decade of tense ...

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and China's top officials signaled a major shift in bilateral relations Thursday as the two countries signed an economic and trade cooperation roadmap alongside six initial agreements covering energy, food safety, and other sectors during the first visit to Beijing by a Canadian leader in eight years.

Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi characterized Carney's four-day state visit as a "turning point" in ties between the two nations, telling Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Anita Anand that the progress would "open up new prospects for bilateral relations" amid what he described as "unprecedented and complex changes taking place in the world."[1][2][3]

items.title: Rice quantum simulator reveals how vibrations drive energy flow in molecules

featured_image.name: Quantum simulator reveals how vibrations steer energy flow ...

items.description:
Researchers at Rice University have built a quantum device capable of simulating molecular vibrations and directly observing how energy moves from one part of a molecule to another, findings that could deepen understanding of natural processes like photosynthesis and improve designs for solar energy technology.

The work, published Dec. 5 in Nature Communications, marks the first time scientists have used trapped-ion technology to simulate a two-mode molecular system while independently controlling energy loss to the environment, according to the research team.[1][2]

items.title: Space economy markets forecast to double by 2030

featured_image.name: Investors pour record $3.5 billion into space as investors ... - Reuters

items.description:
Multiple sectors of the space economy are projected to surge over the next five years as governments and private investors pour unprecedented funding into satellite services, orbital manufacturing, space habitats, and rescue operations.

New market research reports released January 15, 2026, by ResearchAndMarkets.com detail growth trajectories across several emerging space economy segments. The space currency and economy market is forecast to grow from $1.91 billion in 2026 to $3.8 billion by 2030, while in-space manufacturing, servicing, and transportation is expected to expand from $2.6 billion to $5.23 billion during the same period. Space habitat development is projected to reach $11.54 billion by 2030, growing at a compound annual growth rate of 20.8%.[1][2][3]

items.title: TSMC posts record profit as AI chip demand surges

featured_image.name: TSMC Q4 profit poised to soar 27% as AI demand drives growth ...

items.description:
Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the world's largest contract chipmaker, reported record fourth-quarter results on Thursday, with net profit surging 35% year-over-year to NT$505.74 billion ($16 billion), exceeding analyst expectations and fueling a rally across global semiconductor stocks.

The Taiwanese chipmaker announced revenue of NT$1.046 trillion ($33.7 billion) for the quarter ending December 31, marking a 20.5% increase from the previous year. TSMC also revealed plans to substantially increase capital expenditure to between $52 billion and $56 billion in 2026, up from $40.9 billion last year, and projected approximately 30% revenue growth for the full year.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Prometheus claims new process cuts synthetic jet fuel costs by 80%

featured_image.name: Prometheus Just Changed Energy and Fuels Forever

items.description:
Santa Cruz-based Prometheus Fuels has announced what it calls a revolutionary method to produce synthetic jet fuel and diesel from electricity and air, claiming the process reduces e-fuel production costs by more than 80 percent compared to century-old Fischer-Tropsch technology.[1][2][3]

The announcement, made on January 14, marks the first public disclosure of the company's proprietary electrochemical pathway for producing synthetic paraffinic kerosene, the basis for sustainable aviation fuel and e-diesel. According to the company, the process is the first in history to produce kerosene from electricity and atmospheric CO2 without using hydrogen.[3][4][1]

items.title: AI pioneer Bengio says he's confident safe AI is possible

featured_image.name: AI 'godfather' Yoshua Bengio says he's found a fix for AI's biggest ...

items.description:
Yoshua Bengio, the Turing Award-winning AI pioneer often called one of the "godfathers" of artificial intelligence, says his latest research has dramatically shifted his outlook on the future of superintelligent AI. In a recent interview with Fortune, Bengio expressed renewed optimism about humanity's ability to build safe AI systems, citing progress at his nonprofit organization LawZero.[1][2][3]

"Because of the work I've been doing at LawZero, especially since we created it, I'm now very confident that it is possible to build AI systems that don't have hidden goals, hidden agendas," Bengio told Fortune, adding that his optimism has increased "by a big margin" over the past year.[4][2]

items.title: New self-healing composite could extend aircraft lifespans to centuries

featured_image.name: Research: Overcoming longstanding challenges for self ...

items.description:
Researchers at North Carolina State University have developed a self-healing composite material capable of repairing itself more than 1,000 times, a breakthrough that could extend the lifespan of aircraft wings, wind turbine blades, and spacecraft components from decades to centuries.

The study, published this week in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, demonstrates what researchers call "century-scale fracture recovery" in fiber-reinforced polymer composites—materials prized for their high strength-to-weight ratio but long plagued by a failure mode known as delamination.[1][2]

items.title: Study finds ocean damage nearly doubles climate cost estimates

featured_image.name: Study Finds Ocean Impacts Nearly Double Economic Cost of ...

items.description:
The economic toll of climate change on the world's oceans has been vastly underestimated, according to new research that for the first time puts a price tag on marine ecosystem degradation—findings that emerge alongside a separate study warning that proposed climate engineering solutions carry their own risks to ocean life.

Research published Wednesday in the journal Nature Climate Change by scientists at Scripps Institution of Oceanography at UC San Diego found that factoring ocean damage into climate calculations nearly doubles the global cost of carbon dioxide emissions. The study introduces what researchers call the "blue" social cost of carbon, adding $46.2 per ton of CO2 to existing estimates, bringing the total to $97.2 per ton—a 91% increase.[1][2]

items.title: Denmark says White House talks failed to shift Trump's Greenland stance

featured_image.name: Can the US put a price tag on Greenland?

items.description:
Despite President Donald Trump's intensifying push to gain control of Greenland, experts warn that the Arctic territory's severe climate, remote geography, and absent infrastructure pose obstacles that no change in sovereignty could overcome. The island's vast mineral wealth remains locked beneath ice and rock that have defied extraction efforts for decades.

"If you're going to go to Greenland for its minerals, you're talking billions upon billions upon billions of dollars and extremely long time before anything ever comes of it," mineral industry analyst Louis Marchese told Fortune, offering a sobering assessment of the mining reality.[1]

items.title: Amazon opens sovereign cloud in Germany to ease EU data fears

featured_image.name: AWS seeks to allay security fears with new European ...

items.description:
Amazon on Thursday launched its AWS European Sovereign Cloud, a new independent cloud infrastructure designed specifically for Europe that is physically and legally separate from the company's other data centers worldwide. The move addresses growing European concerns about data sovereignty and the dominance of U.S. technology companies in the region's cloud computing market.

The first AWS Region of the sovereign cloud opened in the German state of Brandenburg, which surrounds Berlin. Amazon plans to invest more than €7.8 billion in the AWS European Sovereign Cloud in Germany through 2040, according to the company, with the investment expected to support an average of 2,800 full-time equivalent jobs annually and add approximately €17.2 billion to Germany's GDP.[1][2][3]

items.title: Climate report warns warming may hit catastrophic levels by 2050

featured_image.name: World warming faster than forecast as pollution cuts remove hidden ...

items.description:
Governments and financial institutions have underestimated climate change risks that could undermine the global economy, according to a new report warning that temperatures are rising faster than predicted and could hit catastrophic levels by 2050.

The Parasol Lost report, jointly produced by the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries (IFoA) and the University of Exeter, was released on Tuesday as new data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service confirmed 2025 was the third-warmest year on record. For the first time, the three-year average from 2023 to 2025 has exceeded 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels — the threshold nations pledged not to breach under the 2015 Paris Agreement.[1][2]

items.title: China calls Carney visit a 'turning point' in relations

featured_image.name: China's 2025 Canadian import slump to remind visiting Carney of economic stakes

items.description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney arrived in Beijing on Wednesday for a four-day state visit, marking the first trip by a Canadian leader to China since 2017 and signaling both nations' desire to repair ties strained by years of diplomatic tensions.
